thread.title: Seven ways to get into the Australian property market
thread.title_full: Seven ways to get into the Australian property market

author: ANTHONY KEANE
title: Seven ways to get into the Australian property market
text:
There are several strategies to help Australians get started in property.
ANTHONY KEANE GETTING a foot in the property door is tough amid high house prices and tighter lending rules.
Despite record low interest rates, many potential first homebuyers find the thought of saving tens of thousands of dollars for a deposit just too daunting.
However, there are strategies to prevent the real estate door being slammed in your face for decades.
MONEYSAVERHQ'S FIRST HOME BUYER'S GUIDE
Here are seven steps that might help you stick your foot in and keep it there.
1 SCRIMP AND SAVE
Every dollar counts. From cutting out a few little luxuries to rethinking living arrangements, most people are surprised at how small regular savings can quickly add up.
“Everyone is different, but there is fat to be trimmed from every budget and it can amount to hundreds of dollars each month,” says People’s Choice Credit Union spokesman Stuart Symonds. “Online budget planner calculators can help you find the savings.
“You may need to give up your privacy by moving in with family member or roommates to save a deposit more quickly.”
2 CO-OWNERSHIP
“You can pool your borrowing power with family and friends and co-own a property, while retaining control over your own mortgage ,” Symons says.
However, any co-ownership agreements need to be carefully put together, with exit strategies in place, to avoid a bust-up down the track.
Scrimp and save and your first home will deposit will gradually accumulate. Source: Supplied
3 FAMILY HELP
Baby Boomer parents are increasingly acting as temporary guarantors for their children’s mortgages, putting up their own home’s equity towards the deposit, says Oracle Lending Solutions director Angelo Benedetti.
“A financial guarantee can get you into the market much quicker, and once the property goes up in value or the loan is paid down you can relinquish the parents’ property as security,” he says.
4 INVESTOR FIRST
Many first-home buyers are investors, buying smaller and cheaper properties while still living at home with mum and dad.
Their loan is partly paid by the tenant, they get a tax deduction for the interest paid and other things such as depreciation, and — hopefully — the property grows over time and increases their equity.
FIND THE BEST TERM DEPOSIT ACCOUNTS
A longer loan term can help first home buyers worried about high repayments. Source: Supplied
5 GRANTS ARE GOOD
It’s not the government grant free-for-all that first home buyers enjoyed during the Global Financial Crisis, but there are still some incentives available for new buyers, particularly for new homes.
Check with a local real estate expert or your state government’s website.
6 LENGTHEN THE LOAN
A longer loan term — perhaps 40 years rather than 30 years — can help first home buyers worried about high repayments, Symons says.
“It will bring monthly repayments down and you can reduce the term of the loan when your circumstances change.”
7 JUST DO IT
It worked for Nike and can work for you. “You are better off getting into the market sooner rather than later — some people wait for that bigger, more expensive property and they don’t have enough deposit,” Benedetti says.
“Lower your entry point, get into the market, and if you can build equity in your property by reducing your loan you have got a lot more to play with.”
